## a.

The goal of the assignment is to define off-balance sheet financing.

So far we have used the balance sheet to reflect the assets and liabilities of the entity, but imagine what would happen if an instrument of production is used in the activities of the entity but does not belong to the entity?

This question leads us to the context in which the term **off-balance sheet financing**, where ***assets and liabilities are not recorded off the balance sheet***, begins to make sense. 

So we can define **off-balance sheet financing** as the activity of not reporting on the balance sheet the assets and liabilities associated with a lease. 

Note that the ratios calculated from the balance sheet will be affected: the ***debt and leverage ratios would remain low***. This is one of the reasons why the use of the practice of **off-balance sheet financing** should follow the proper accounting rules and regulations.

## b.

The goal of this assignment is to explain what a capital lease is for accounting purposes.

In a lease contract that grants the right to use an asset to the lessee for the determined period, and there are economic characteristics of the ownership of the asset for accounting purposes, then this contract is considered a **capital lease**. In Figure 1 we can observe the criteria that we will take into account to classify a capital lease:

Figure 1. Criteria for a lease is considered a capital lease.

If we found only one of these criteria we can state that we are in presence of a **capital lease**.
